title: Importance of Cancer Screening
content: Cancer screening is important as it helps in early detection of cancer, making it easier to treat. The evidence suggests that a cancer that is caught earlier is easier to treat than a cancer that is caught later. For instance, if you catch a breast cancer or a colon cancer when there are tens or hundreds of millions of cancer cells, your odds of treating that successfully are better than if you catch the same cancer years later, when there are billions of cells. The more we can do to screen for cancer and catch it earlier, the better we will be.

title: Cancer Screening Terms: Sensitivity, Specificity, False Positives, and False Negatives
content: Sensitivity is the probability that the test yields a positive result for someone who has the condition of interest. A sensitive test is likely to detect a person who has the condition if they’re tested. Specificity, on the other hand, is the probability that a bunch of people who do not have the condition will also end up with a negative test. False positives and false negatives are potential outcomes of these tests.

title: Improving Predictive Value by Layering Tests
content: Layering and stacking different tests in tandem can improve predictive values. This approach can help in improving the accuracy of cancer screening.

title: Impact of Smoking on Cancer Screening
content: Smoking impacts the predictive value of cancer screening. It can potentially increase the risk of false positives and negatives, affecting the accuracy of the screening.

title: Liquid Biopsies for Cancer Screening
content: Liquid biopsies can be used for ruling out cancer. However, they have certain blind spots and may not be able to detect all types of cancers.

title: Diffusion-Weighted MRI in Cancer Screening
content: Diffusion-weighted MRI is changing the landscape of cancer screening. It is one of the more exciting screening tools that has the potential to improve the accuracy and effectiveness of cancer detection.

title: Understanding Specificity and Sensitivity
content: Specificity is the number of true negatives over the total number of cases, the true negatives plus the false positives. As specificity goes up, your ability to discern negatives goes up. As sensitivity goes up, your ability to discern positives goes up. As sensitivity goes up, your true positives go up and your false negatives go down.

title: The Metal Detector Analogy
content: A metal detector in the airport is used as an analogy to explain sensitivity and specificity. If you want it to be very sensitive, that means you never want to have a false negative. Your true positives are going to go very high. You’re going to catch everybody. And your false negatives are going to be very low. On the flip side, you’re going to get a lot of false positives. Which means you’re going to be dinging a lot of people for metal who don’t have metal.

title: Cancer Screening Terms: Positive and Negative Predictive Value
content: The positive predictive value is defined as the number of true positives over the true positives + the false positives (the tested positives versus all the positives). A high positive predictive value means if you get a positive test, here’s how confident you are that your test is truly positive. Similarly, the negative predictive value are the true negatives. So if you had a 50% negative predictive value, it would mean that only half the people for whom a negative test is the outcome are actually negative for the condition.

title: Interactive Spreadsheet for Predictive Values
content: An interactive spreadsheet allows you to input population, prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity. These factors determine the positive and negative predictive values. The prevalence of a condition in a population can greatly affect the predictive values. For example, the prevalence of cancer in a group of 60 year old smokers is much higher than a 30 year old who is a totally healthy nonsmoker.

title: Improving Predictive Value by Layering Tests
content: If you do one particular test, so for mammography for example, maybe it doesn’t mean right away that you get a biopsy. Instead, maybe you do another test on top of that and you might actually be able to get a better positive predictive value. That’s effectively how we think about cancer screening.

title: Layering Tests for Breast Cancer
content: The best way to detect breast cancer with today’s technology is mammography plus MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging. This method minimizes radiation because the mammography is very low radiation. Diffusion-weighted imaging with background subtraction can pick up things that no other test can pick up. However, diffusion-weighted imaging misses something that mammograms pick up— small calcified lesions. If you have dense breast tissue, if you have glandular breast tissue, you’re going to get a lot of false positives. That’s why ultrasound or MRI as a backup is a great way to avoid the unnecessary biopsies that plagued many women for decades.

title: Impact of Smoking on Cancer Screening
content: If you look at a population of smokers and you’re looking at screening, you’re going to have a higher prevalence. One study showed ~70 year old individuals with a two pack a day smoking habit for 50 years would have a pretest probability of the prevalence of about 15%. That pretest probability of the prevalence is going to change the landscape in terms of the predictive value of a test—if you’ve got a higher prevalence, you’re going to have more predictive value with that.

title: Liquid Biopsies for Cancer Screening
content: A liquid biopsy is a biopsy of the blood (essentially a blood sample). The goal here is to be able to infer through a blood test if a person has a solid organ tumor. A company called GRAIL has basically developed a technology of both sequencing and machine learning that takes blood and looks for something called cell-free DNA fragments. When cancer is present, the methylation profile of cfDNA or cell-free DNA changes. It’s that CF or cell-free DNA methylation pattern that is what allows people to in the case of these machine learning algorithms infer that a cancer is present AND what the likely tissue of origin is.

title: Specificity and Sensitivity of Liquid Biopsies
content: Preliminarily, what we know is that the test increases in sensitivity as cancer stages goes up. The specificity on this test is very high – about 99.5%. But the sensitivity starts low with stage one cancers – about 20%, stage two cancers – about 45%, Stage three cancers – about 81%, Stage four cancers – about 93%. For all local cancers—stage one, two, and three—it’s a 44% sensitivity. For all cancers all told, it’s about a 55% sensitivity, 99.3% specificity.

title: Prostate Cancer Screening
content: Multiplanar MRI is incredible for prostate cancer. So is PSA despite the fact that most people don’t think it is, but that’s because most people just look at PSA when they should be paying closer attention to PSA density and PSA velocity. You have other blood tests like the 4K diagnostic test, which doesn’t just look at PSA and free PSA, but looks at two other proteins and has tremendous accuracy at not just determining if prostate cancer is present, but determining if aggressive prostate cancer is present.

title: Cancer Originating from Inside vs Outside the Body
content: Outside the body would be things like melanoma or even colon cancer. It’s exposed to the outside world, which means you can look at it directly, you can look at it with your eyes. Inside the body cancer is tougher. Examples: Brain cancers, breast cancers, lung cancers, pancreatic cancers, liver cancer, kidney cancer, prostate cancer, sarcomas, cancers of the connective tissue. Cancers that you can’t look at with the naked eye. And liquid biopsies can hopefully give us a great insight into this coupled with all of these other types of screenings.

title: Diffusion-Weighted MRI in Cancer Screening
content: Everything that is happening with an MRI is basically manipulating a hydrogen atom with a very, very strong magnet. The two most common sequences in MRI are called T1 and T2-weighted images. They basically highlight different elements of the anatomy.

title: MRI Imaging Techniques
content: A T1-weighted image is a very anatomically beautiful image – it tends to highlight fat. A T2-weighted image conversely is not as anatomically nice, but it’s still a very helpful image especially, for example, if you’re looking at the spine. If someone’s getting a dedicated MRI of their spine and you want to truly understand the nature of the discs, the intervertebral discs, the T2-weighted image is really good.

title: Diffusion-Weighted Imaging
content: Diffusion-weighted imaging with background subtraction (DWIBS) is looking at water, but it’s doing so across two points of time. It’s doing so at two very small points of time, which is about 60 microseconds. When you consider how ubiquitous water is in our body, even over 60 microseconds, water should be moving. But if it doesn’t, then it tells us that that water is somehow trapped. This is what makes diffusion-weighted imaging a little bit more of a functional test than an imaging test.

title: CT Scan vs PET Scan
content: A CT scan is an image that shows anatomic detail. Whereas a PET scan is a functional study—it shows glucose uptake by tissue so it’s not really trying to show you a nice picture where you can infer the minutiae of the vascular system of the liver or the pancreas. Instead, it’s just trying to say, “Look, here’s an area where a lot of cells are taking up glucose.”

title: DWI and Cancer Detection
content: The DWI is more akin to the latter (the PET scan)— It’s basically showing you the darker something is on that scan, the firmer that tissue is. And that becomes very relevant in the setting of cancer, because cancer feels different than non-cancer. For example: women doing a self exam for a lump on their breasts. By feeling, palpating over breast tissue, if you feel a lump, that is a concern because cancer is firm.

title: Cancer Screening Approach
content: The approach to cancer screening includes screening often, early, and aggressively. Important tests include widely utilizing the liquid biopsy, utilizing the full body MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging, mammography, cervical exam, colonoscopy, endoscopy, dermatologic exam, ophthalmologic exam for ocular melanoma. In men, PSA with PSA velocity, PSA volume — and if suspicion is high, they will do a Four-kallikrein test (4k score). All of this is tailored to a person — they don’t have an algorithm that they would apply to all people.
